item.name: label
item.presentation: A bullet, A, is shot into a block, B, as shown.  The block splits into pieces, C and D, with the bullet embedded in piece D.  Before the collision, the block was sitting on a smooth tabletop.  If we were to "solve the collision", we would be interested in the velocity of piece C of the block just after the impact of the bullet.

item.name: Is the system (at least approximately) isolated? Why or why not?
item.label: answer
item.presentation: r>>>>>No, because of friction between the tabletop and the block. |No, because the block splits into pieces, and so there are more objects after the collision than there were before the collision. |Yes, the friction between the block and the tabletop must be weak compared to the interaction between the block and the bullet. |Yes, because no matter enters the system.
